forms.english: I was killed - ἀποκτείνω root απο + *κτεν
he was spoiled, wiped out, ruined
to trust, be confident, rely upon
so that, in order that, how that
I carried, bore, produced - φέρω  root ?
I have been persuaded - πείθω root *πειθ
he was heavy, he was honored
he was sorry, moved to pity, had compassion
I was opened, unlocked, disclosed - ἀνοίγω root ανα + *οιγω
he delighted in, desired, was willing
I have cried out, called out - κράζω root *κραγ
they praised, gave thanks - יָדָה - he cast
he be(came) complete, came to an end, ceased, was consumed, was spent, was burned out
he redeemed, delivered, acted as kinsman, avenged
I will tie, bind - δέω root δε ?
he inherited, he possessed, he dispossessed
he was complete, finished, he came to an end
he covered over, pacified, made propitiation
I call, cry out - root φωνε ?
he gave rest to, he set down
I praised, honored, glorified - δοξάζω root *δοξαδ
I have been asked - αἰτέω root *αἰτε
I take up, I take away - root *αρ
I will be made to kill
I will sin - ἁμαρτάνω root ἁμαρτ ?
I was answered - ἀποκρίνομαι root απο + *κριν
I have been known - γινώσκω root *γνω
I have been given - δίδωμι root *δο
I have been done/made - ποιω root *ποιε
I was healed - θεραπεύω root θεραπευ ?
I was brought together, I was compiled συνάγω
I will call, cry out - φωνῶ root φωνε ?
I was tied, bound - δέω root δε ?
whoever, everyone (ὅς + τις both parts decline)
I was given up, given back, paid
I will give up, give back, pay
isolated, desolate, deserted, used as substantive, desert (feminine in this case)
palm of the hand, sole of the foot
I was forgiven - ἀφιημι root απο + *σε
no, not, used with perfect, used with imperfect = never
I have been grasped, have been taken possession - κρατέω root *κρατε
I will bring together, I will compile συνάγω
I have gone up, risen up, advanced - ἀναβαίνω root ανα + *βα
I have been taken, received δέχομαι
with me, NOT direct object marker
I might be loosening myself/be loosened
sinful or out of bounds behavior, as substantive sinner or outsider
I will look at, behold - θεωρέω root *θεωρε
I grasped, was strong, took possession - κρατέω root *κρατε

Greek.rule:
Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * (anything but ε) + ο = ω (commutative)

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ε + ο = ου (commutative)

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * anything + ω = ω (commutative)

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * α + ε/η = α

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ε/η + α  = η

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * α + ε + ι = ᾳ

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ε + α + ι = ῃ

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * ο + ε + ι = οι

Contract verbs are verbs that end in α, ε, or ο.  In the present and
  imperfect tenses the final vowel contracts with the connecting vowel as follows: 
 * Dipthongs:  if the contract vowel and the first vowel of the dipthong are the
   same, they combine to a single instance of the vowel.  Otherwise they contract.
   If the second vowel of the dipthong is a ι it subscripts if possible.

A deponent verb is one that is middle or passive in form but active
in meaning.  It does not take a middle or passive meaning.
Verbs can be deponent in one tense but not in another (e.g. ἔρχομαι is deponent in
the present but not in the aorist.)
75% of middle forms in the NT are deponent.

Separating γινομαι, γενναω and γινωσκω:
 * γινομαι will always have a vowel between the γ and the ν.  Usually an ε.
 * γενναω always has double ν and is completely regular.
 * γινωσκω, except in the present tense, does not have a vowel between the γ and the ν.

Verb roots and stems
Pattern 1: root not modified.  Example: *ἀκου

Verb roots and stems
Pattern 2: different roots in different stems

Verb roots and stems
Verbs that have second aorists are normally verbs that alter their
     root in the formation of their present tense stem.

Verb roots and stems
Pattern 3: verbs with roots ending in a liquid (λ, μ, ν, ρ)

Verb roots and stems
Tense formative for future is εσ instead of just σ but σ often drops out
     when placed between two vowels resulting in future without σ.
     The contracted vowels always have a circumflex (except in 1st plural middle).
     For example: μεν + εσ + ω = μεν + ε + ω = μενῶ

Verb roots and stems
When the present tense stem ends in ιζω or αζω the root generally ends in a
   dental (τ, δ, θ) *βαπτιδ -> βαπτιζω

Verb roots and stems
When the present tense stem ends in ασσω the root generally ends in a
   velar (κ, γ, χ) *ταραχ -> ταρασσω

Verb roots and stems
When the present tense stem ends in a double consonant the root often ends in
   a single consonant: *βαλ -> βαλλω

Verb roots and stems
Some roots add a iota in the present stem: *αρ -> αἴρω
